awd_abstract_narration:
Leveraging knowledge about how "Making" actively engages participants in authentic science and engineering practices, the University of Hawaii MakerSTEM project explores a new model for teacher preparation in secondary science education. Pre-service teachers will design and iterate their own science investigations and classroom instructional materials in a makerspace lab studio at the Hawaii Institute for Marine Biology. While much emphasis has been placed on providing maker opportunities for students, teachers also need these experiences to become qualified mentors and proficient facilitators of modern STEM learning. MakerSTEM will help pre-service teachers in Hawaii to develop proficiency in scientific investigation and design practices, and to become innovators of student-driven active learning. The cumulative impact over the course of a single teacher's career could reach 4,500 students. If successful, this maker-based approach can be transferred to other teacher training programs, potentially transforming K-12 science education by empowering teachers with deep pedagogical content knowledge and skills that align with 21st Century STEM careers.

The intellectual merit of this project includes investigation of 1) the efficacy of applying makerspace design principles to a science teacher credential program and 2) the impact of MakerSTEM lab environment on pre-service teacher STEM learning and practice through a longitudinal case-study approach. Knowledge gained from this research will result in a new heuristic model for how making can be effectively incorporated into STEM teacher education. This line of investigation will begin to further inform evidence-based teaching practices to improve learning outcomes and contribute to a generalized grounded theory of STEM learning in college maker labs. These insights may catalyze novel possibilities for the way science and science education is offered on college campuses. The potential for communities of learners to emerge within university maker labs may remodel the overall STEM college learning experience, enabling students to address student-defined problems and build collaborative partnerships in a way that parallels professional practices.

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview:

The National Science Foundation (NSF)-funded project, "EAGER:Maker:University of Hawaii MakerSTEM," aimed work with secondary educators to transfrom their STEM education practices by promoting inquiry, exploration, and tinkering related to real-world problem-solving. Over the course of four years, this project achieved several key outcomes that have significantly contributed to the enhancement of STEM education.

Outcome 1: Curriculum Development for Partner Programs

One of the primary outcomes of this project was the development of innovative STEM curricula, which were designed to foster student inquiry, exploration, and hands-on learning. These curricula were implemented successfully in MakerSTEM led professional development experiences and with partner programs, such as the Science, Techknowledgy, Engineering, Mathematics, Social Sciences and Sense of Place (STEMS^2) masters progam at University of Hawaii - Manoa. The curricular materials emphasized the integration of art and science will providing tools and resources to support teacher and student probelms solving though active wondering and tinkering. Curricula provided educators with the tools and resources needed to engage students in meaningful STEM activities. Feedback from partner programs indicated that the new curricula have had a profound impact on their teaching practices and student learning outcomes.

Outcome 2: Sustained Partnerships for MakerLab Model Sustainability

The project established strong and sustained partnerships with educational institutions and community organizations. These partnerships are instrumental in ensuring the sustainability of the MakerLab model beyond the life of the grant. Collaborative efforts with stakeholders from diverse backgrounds have resulted in continued access to MakerLab resources and expertise, enabling ongoing innovation STEM education practices. This sustainability ensures that the project's impact endures well beyond the grant period.

Outcome 3: Local and National Conference Presentations

The project team actively disseminated its findings and innovations at local, national, and international conferences. Presentations were made at prestigious conferences, including the 2019 American Educational Research Association (AERA) annual meetin in Toronto and the 2021 National Association for Research in Science Teaching (NARST) annual meeting on-line. Findings where also shared at local conferences such as the 2018 Hawaii Science Teachers and Assessment (HaSTA) annual conference. We are particularly proud of our ability to create opportunites for teacher participants to share their work at national conferences such as FabLearn in 2020. These presentations allowed for the sharing of best practices, lessons learned, and insights gained from the project. They also facilitated valuable networking and collaboration opportunities with educators and researchers from various institutions and backgrounds.

Outcome 4: Publications in Process

Two publications are currently in process as a result of this project. These publications include one research article and practitioner-oriented materials resource guide that detail the project's methodologies, outcomes, and insights. The dissemination of these publications will further contribute to the broader educational community's understanding of the impact of the MakerLab model on teacher professional development and student engagement.

Outcome 5: Impactful for Teacher Participants

Perhaps one of the most significant outcomes of this project is its impact on teacher participants. Through professional development workshops, collaboration with colleagues, and the implementation of MakerLab-based curricula, participating teachers have reported substantial modifications to their teaching practices. They have embraced a pedagogical approach that places greater emphasis on student inquiry, exploration, and tinkering related to real-world problem-solving. Teachers report observing increased student engagement, and a heightened interest in STEM subjects among their students.

Conclusion:

Though greatly impacted by three years of the COVID-19 pandemic, the "EAGER:Maker:University of Hawaii MakerSTEM" project has experienced significant success through the development of innovative curricula, the establishment of sustained partnerships, presentations at local and national conferences, ongoing publications, and meaningful impacts on participating teachers. These outcomes collectively contribute to the project's goal of promoting inquiry-based, wonder and tinkering in STEM education, ultimately benefitting students and educators alike. The project's legacy is expected to endure, fostering a culture of innovation and exploration in STEM education for years to come.

 


Last Modified: 09/19/2023
Modified by: Tara O'neill
